facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 143 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 143 of 1970. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated 31st October 1969 of Delhi High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 70 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 31st October, 1969 of the Delhi High Court at New Delhi in Criminal Appeal No. 70

facts.text: Appellant is a quondam inspector of Central Excise.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, a quondam inspector of Central Excise, has argued his case with perspicacity and plausibility, taking liberal advantage

facts.text: Charge is corruption under s.161 IPC and s.5(1)(d) read with s.5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The charge broadly stated, is one of corruption falling under s.161,I.P.C. and S. 5 1  d , read with s.5 2 , of the prevention of Corruption Act, 1947

facts.text: Proof of guilt built on trap by Special Police Establishment using chemical detection.

anchor.surface_text: the proof of guilt is built on a trap laid by the Special Police Establishment, apparently clinched by processes of chemical detection

facts.text: PW1 started small factory in Shadara called Uma Engineering Corporation for making insulated copper cables around June 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the story, P. W. 1, a young man in his late twenties, had started a small factory in Shadara, called Uma Engineering Corporation, for making insulated copper cables, around June, 1965.

facts.text: Semi-finished goods taken to another factory in Delhi for rubber insulation.

anchor.surface_text: The whole process, except fitting the rubber insulation, was done in his premises and for this latter purpose the semi-finished goods used to be

facts.text: Excise authorities issued gate passes for removal of half-finished items.

anchor.surface_text: taken to another factory in Delhi. Insulated coppers being dutiable articles, the Excise authorities had to issue gate passes for removal of even half

facts.text: Practice prevailed till before offence: removal for completion without advance duty.

anchor.surface_text: finished items. According to a certain practice that prevailed till a little before the alleged commission of the offence, when the article was not fully

facts.text: Accused insisted even removal for further processing only on payment of duty.

anchor.surface_text: manufactured, its removal for the completion of the process was permitted without levy of duty in advance and gate passes were issued on this basis.

facts.text: Assistant Collector per Exhibit D-1 upheld accused: duty paid clearance or bonds r.56A.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, the Assistant Collector, as per Exhibit D-1, upheld the accuseds stand directed duty paid clearance or adherence to the system of bonds

facts.text: Duty paid finished goods could not leave without pro forma c.1. Ex. D-2 filled, verified and signed by Excise inspector.

anchor.surface_text: for payment later, according to r. 56 A of the relevant rules. Apart from this, even duty paid finished goods could not leave the factory premises

facts.text: PW1 contacted accused and was asked to pay Rs.100 monthly as speed money.

anchor.surface_text: The embryonic industrialist, P. W. 1, when faced with the insistence on duty payment made contacts with the accused and was asked to initiate himself

facts.text: PW1 went to Sri Waswani, Deputy Superintendent Central Excise, with little benefit.

anchor.surface_text: into the magical means of getting things done through monthly payments of Rs. 100/-as speed money. Being too virgin for this way to prosperity, P.W. 1

facts.text: On August 4, 1965, PW1 met accused for verification of statement of manufactured goods to pay duty, turned back without Rs.100.

anchor.surface_text: Again, on August 4, 1965, he met the accused for getting him to verify the statement of manufactured goods to pay the duty thereon, but was turned back,

facts.text: On August 6, 1965, PW1 went to accused office for clearance of 2 finished bundles of cables.

anchor.surface_text: We now move to the critical phase. On August 6. 1965, P. W. 1 goes to the office of the accused to get clearance of 2 finished bundles of cables.

facts.text: Accused demanded money, PW1 bargained to Rs.50, accused signed challan Ex P4 for duty deposit.

anchor.surface_text: The demand for money is repeated but by this time P. W. 1 acquires skill in courtship and bargains for a smaller sum of Rs. 50/. Whereupon the accused

facts.text: Bribe fixed to be paid next day afternoon.

anchor.surface_text: signs the challan for the deposit of the excise duty on these finished products  vide Ex. P. 4 . The bribe, according to the understanding, is fixed

facts.text: Next morning PW1 disclosed to SPE officers at Kotah House Ex P5.

anchor.surface_text: to be paid next day in the afternoon. At this stage, P. W. 1 changes his mind and discloses his bosom to the S. P. E. Officers the next morning at Kotah

facts.text: Raiding party went to factory, accused arrived, tea served, PW1 passed Rs50 to accused pockets.

anchor.surface_text: Now the scene shifts to the factory. The accused arrives, tea is served, the treacherous notes are passed and put into his gullible pockets by the unsuspecting

facts.text: Signal given, police entered, accused surrendered currency notes.

facts.text: Chemical test: hands, kerchief, inner lining of trouser pocket of accused turned positive (violet) in sodium carbonate solution.

anchor.surface_text: his hands, kerchief and inner lining of the trouser pocket betray him when dipped in acidic solution and the game is up. Such is the prosecution version

facts.text: Special Judge convicted accused.

anchor.surface_text: The inexorable course of the law takes the accused to the special Judge who convicts him,

facts.text: High Court affirmed guilt but reduced sentence to one year imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court affirms the guilt but reduces the sentence to one years imprisonment.

issues.text: Whether the Supreme Court under Article 136 should interfere with the concurrent findings of fact upholding the accused's culpability absent perversity or miscarriage of justice?

holdings.text: There is no good ground to overturn the factual findings recorded by the trial judge and affirmed on appeal under Article 136.

anchor.surface_text: To sum up, we see nogood ground to over-turn the factual findings recorded by the trial judge and affirmed on appeal. The Central Law Commission considering white-collar crime as a serious menace has made a report on the subject,and the Sanyal Committee has much earlier highlighted the dangers in this area.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of guilt by Special Judge and High Court lack perversity or miscarriage of justice; Art 136 power exceptional and rarely used for factual re-appraisal.

holdings.text: The evidence of PW7 and PW8 is substantially correct and the bona fides of the trap accepted.

anchor.surface_text: we are prepared to agree with the High Court that the evidence of P.Ws.7 and 8 are substantially correct Even here, we must underscore the importance of the findings of the trap experiment, since they go a long way to underwrite the veracity, of the prosecution story,

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court accepted after careful study; rulings require caution and corroboration, not blanket rejection; SPE officers credible; no evidence of taint.

holdings.text: Chemical test results on accused's hands, handkerchief, and trouser pocket lining corroborate acceptance of tainted notes; no alternative hypothesis explains the colour change.

anchor.surface_text: The fact is indisputable that the hands, the handkerchief and the inner lining of the trouser pocket of the accused turned violet when dipped in soda ash solution. From this the State counsel argues that on nohypothesis-except that the notes emerged from tile accused pocket or possession can the triple colour change be accounted for.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Indisputable violet reaction; accused's contamination theory via coke bottle and dipping rejected as recondite by lower courts; science corroborates oral evidence.

holdings.text: Testimonies of PW1, PW3, PW4, PW7, and PW8 are credible and sufficient to prove passing and acceptance of bribe beyond reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of P. W. 4 coupled with that of P. W. 1, was itself sufficient to establish the acceptance of the tainted currency notes by the appellant from Om Prakash, which was a pivotal fact of the prosecution case. Then, there was the evidence of P. W. 3, apart from that of the police officers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: PW1 animus noted but corroborated; PW4 gazetted officer, no animus, presence admitted, contradictions inconsequential; PW7/PW8 substantially correct; trap findings support.

holdings.text: Bribe as speed money provides motive even for expediting lawful acts like signing gate passes and pro formas after duty payment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Time is money for business; discretionary signatures can be delayed to extract bribe; applies even post Ex D-1 duty regime; supported by observations on administrative lubricant.

holdings.text: Accused guilty under s.161 IPC and s.5(1)(d) read with s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act; conviction and reduced sentence upheld.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court affirms the guilt but reduces the sentence to one years imprisonment. The arguments in this Court, if confined to facts only under art136, have as much chance as the proverbial camel through the eye of a needle.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trap, chemical test, witness testimonies prove demand, acceptance, pocketing of Rs.50 bribe; concurrent findings affirmed; no overturn under Art 136.

holdings.text: Trap evidence not per se tainted; requires caution, corroboration, and scrutiny of bona fides depending on circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: The basic attack has been on the morally murky mechanism of criminal trap. [...] Judicial attitudes have to be discriminating, as has happened in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Traps necessary to combat corruption given proof difficulties; precedents indicate caution not rejection; discrimination based on facts.

holdings.text: Reduction of sentence to one year by High Court left undisturbed as State has not appealed.

anchor.surface_text: However, since the State has not quarrelled with the reduction of sentence by way of appeal we leave the matter well alone.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural; State acquiescence; though leniency possibly erroneous given white-collar crime menace.

anchor.surface_text: To sum up, we see no good ground to over-turn the factual findings recorded by the trial judge and affirmed on appeal. The Central Law Commission considering white-collar crime as a serious menace has made a report on the subject,and the Senthanan Committee has much earlier highlighted the dangers in this area. ,In this social context judicial severity cannot err on the high side an we think the ends of justice referred to by the High Court for toning ,down the sentence is perhaps an error on the side of leniency. If at all, intensive efforts to track down bigger companyruption must be made but companyrts cannot slow down because bigger criminals are number caught ,although public morals is boosted better by one big fish being caught ,in the criminal number than by a hundred small fry perishing ashore, However, since the State has number quarrelled with the reduction of sentence by way of appeal we leave the matter well alone.

outcome.relief_summary: Concurrent findings of guilt upheld; no ground to overturn conviction; sentence as reduced by High Court left undisturbed

anchor.surface_text: To sum up, we see nogood ground to over-turn the factual findings recorded by the trial judge and affirmed on appeal. The Central Law Commission considering white-collar crime as a serious menace has made a report on the subject,and the Sanyal Committee has much earlier highlighted the dangers in this area.

To sum up, we see no good ground to over-turn the factual findings recorded by the trial judge and affirmed on appeal. The Central Law Commission considering white-collar crime as a serious menace has made a report on the subject,and the Senthanan Committee has much earlier highlighted the dangers in this area. ,In this social context judicial severity cannot err on the high side an we think the ends of justice referred to by the High Court for toning ,down the sentence is perhaps an error on the side of leniency. If at all, intensive efforts to track down bigger companyruption must be made but companyrts cannot slow down because bigger criminals are number caught ,although public morals is boosted better by one big fish being caught ,in the criminal number than by a hundred small fry perishing ashore, However, since the State has number quarrelled with the reduction of sentence by way of appeal we leave the matter well alone.

we are prepared to agree with the High Court that the evidence of P.Ws.7 and 8 are substantially correct Even here, we must underscore the importance of the findings of the trap experiment, since they go a long way to underwrite the veracity, of the prosecution story,

anchor.surface_text: The fact is indisputable that the hands, the handkerchief and the inner lining of the trouser pocket of the accused turned violet when dipped in soda ash solution. From this the State counsel argues that on nohypothesis-except that the notes emerged from tile accused pocket or possession can the triple colour change be accounted for.

To sum up, we see no good ground to over-turn the factual findings recorded by the trial judge and affirmed on appeal. The Central Law Commission considering white-collar crime as a serious menace has made a report on the subject,and the Senthanan Committee has much earlier highlighted the dangers in this area. ,In this social context judicial severity cannot err on the high side an we think the ends of justice referred to by the High Court for toning ,down the sentence is perhaps an error on the side of leniency. If at all, intensive efforts to track down bigger companyruption must be made but companyrts cannot slow down because bigger criminals are number caught ,although public morals is boosted better by one big fish being caught ,in the criminal number than by a hundred small fry perishing ashore, However, since the State has number quarrelled with the reduction of sentence by way of appeal we leave the matter well alone.

The evidence of P. W. 4 coupled with that of P. W. 1, was itself sufficient to establish the acceptance of the tainted currency notes by the appellant from Om Prakash, which was a pivotal fact of the prosecution case. Then, there was the evidence of P. W. 3, apart from that of the police officers.

To sum up, we see no good ground to over-turn the factual findings recorded by the trial judge and affirmed on appeal. The Central Law Commission considering white-collar crime as a serious menace has made a report on the subject,and the Senthanan Committee has much earlier highlighted the dangers in this area. ,In this social context judicial severity cannot err on the high side an we think the ends of justice referred to by the High Court for toning ,down the sentence is perhaps an error on the side of leniency. If at all, intensive efforts to track down bigger companyruption must be made but companyrts cannot slow down because bigger criminals are number caught ,although public morals is boosted better by one big fish being caught ,in the criminal number than by a hundred small fry perishing ashore, However, since the State has number quarrelled with the reduction of sentence by way of appeal we leave the matter well alone.
